section: ‚ÄúAll Time‚Äù includes the future, and while Saban might be the greatest in history, when it‚Äôs all said and done, Kirby will be the G.O.A.T.
text: ‚ÄúAll Time‚Äù includes the future, and while Saban might be the greatest in history, when it‚Äôs all said and done, Kirby will be the G.O.A.T.

Nick Saban won‚Äôt be the G.O.A.T.


An NFL Draft Perspective


By: Ben Leathers


2023-04-17














Clickbait headline aside, Nick Saban is unquestionably the greatest coach in history. However, the interesting thing about ‚Äúall time‚Äù is that it includes the future. Kirby Smart is only 7 seasons into his career as a head coach, and he‚Äôs been quite prolific when it comes to putting players into the draft. How has his career start compared to other coaches beginning their careers, including Nick Saban?








How well has UGA put players into the draft while Kirby Smart has been the head coach?












Wow‚Ä¶ could that ‚Äúup and to the right‚Äù trajectory suggest that Kirby‚Äôs good at player development?


You might be thinking to yourself‚Ä¶ ‚ÄúNo, it just suggests he‚Äôs recruiting better players‚Äù which is a reasonable thing to think. Mark Richt is no question a DGD, and he elevated the program during his tenure. That being said, Kirby inherited a roster whose previous 3 recruiting classes had an average ranking of ~9th in the country, whereas Kirby has averaged rankings of ~3 as head coach of UGA. So you would be justified to argue that this upward trajectory just points to better recruiting. But is there more to the story?



It‚Äôs not just better players. Even the 3 stars are more likely to get drafted the longer they play under Kirby.


How do UGA‚Äôs Draft results during Kirby‚Äôs first 6 years compare to other coach‚Äôs first 6 years?



Seeing Jimbo Fisher at #5 was surprising to begin with, but then I remembered he‚Äôs got a reputation for recruiting and he‚Äôs developing a reputation for losing recruits now that the transfer portal is a factor. Mark Richt at #6 is less surprising, he was a great coach who did put a lot of talent into the NFL.


So how did Larry Coker and Jim Tressel out perform Kirby in the first 6 years?



Oh, they stepped into programs with loaded rosters that put 8 and 11 players into the NFL in year 1. Kirby didn‚Äôt inherit a completely bare roster, but it was certainly more modest.


How many UGA players will need to be drafted in order for Kirby to jump into first in year 7?



What Happened to Larry Coker?


He got fired from Miami after going 6-6 and didn‚Äôt coach again until 2012 when he was hired by UTSA.


Let‚Äôs check on some coaches that are noticibly absent from the top ten.



In fairness to Saban he didn‚Äôt start his heach coaching careers at a blue blood football school, so lets compare the results from each school tenure.




Takeaways:


Kirby‚Äôs program develops players.


Kirby‚Äôs Death Star might not have even been fully operational yet‚Ä¶ ü§Ø


‚ÄúAll Time‚Äù includes the future, and while Saban might be the greatest in history, Kirby is on the path to take over and when it‚Äôs all said and done‚Ä¶


Saban will not be the G.O.A.T., Kirby will.


This analysis was based on an open source dataset, cfbd, and while I‚Äôm confident in my work, I am also confident I‚Äôm human, so if you find a mistake, please let me know.

import pandas as pd
import json


def get_coordinator(year):
    if 2000 <= year <= 2006:
        return 'Richt'
    elif 2007 <= year <= 2014:
        return 'Bobo'
    elif 2015 <= year <= 2015:
        return 'Schottenheimer'
    elif 2016 <= year <= 2018:
        return 'Chaney'
    elif 2019 <= year <= 2019:
        return 'Coley'
    elif 2020 <= year <= 2022:
        return 'Monken'
    else:
        return 'NA'

        rankings_df = df_year
    else:
        rankings_df = pd.concat([rankings_df, df_year])


rankings_df['coordinator'] = rankings_df.year.apply(get_coordinator)

import numpy as np
from PIL import Image
# from skimage.segmentation import felzenszwalb
from logo import Logo


IMAGE_SAVE_DIR = 'logos'
TRANSPARENT_BG = 'transparent_bg'
WHITE_BG = 'white_bg'
if not exists(join(IMAGE_SAVE_DIR, TRANSPARENT_BG)):
    os.makedirs(join(IMAGE_SAVE_DIR, TRANSPARENT_BG))
if not exists(join(IMAGE_SAVE_DIR, WHITE_BG)):
    os.makedirs(join(IMAGE_SAVE_DIR, WHITE_BG))


def clean_img(img, bg_color_distance_threshold=10, scale=100, sigma=0., min_size=90):
    # labels = felzenszwalb(img, scale=scale, sigma=sigma, min_size=min_size)
    # np_img = np.array(img)
    # height, width = np_img.shape[:2]
    # np_img[:,:,3][labels == labels[0][0]] = 0
    # np_img[:,:,3][labels == labels[0][width-1]] = 0
    # np_img[:,:,3][labels == labels[height-1][width-1]] = 0
    # np_img[:,:,3][labels == labels[height-1][0]] = 0
    # return Image.fromarray(np_img)
    logo = Logo(img, bg_color_distance_threshold=bg_color_distance_threshold,
                    scale=scale, sigma=sigma, min_size=min_size, character_bounding_threshold=.03)
    return logo.get_bgr(), logo.get_new_bgr()
    


# Retrieve the HTML content
# spans = ['a-c', 'd-h', 'i-m', 'n-r', 's-t', 'u-y']
# spans = ['d-h']
urls = [f'https://www.sportslogos.net/teams/list_by_league/{x}/NCAA_Division_I_a-c/NCAA_a-c/logos/' for x in range(33,37)]
for url in urls:
    print(url)
    response = requests.get(url)
    html = response.content
    soup = BeautifulSoup(html, 'html.parser')
    logos = soup.find("ul", {"class": "logoWall"}).find_all("a")
    for logo in logos:
        filename = logo.text.strip().replace(" ", "_").replace('/','-') + '.png'
        # if 'alabama' not in filename.lower():
        #     continue
        print(logo.text.strip())
        logo_link = logo.img['src']
        response = requests.get(logo_link)
        img = Image.open(BytesIO(response.content)).convert('RGBA')
        cleaned_img = clean_img(img)
        cleaned_img[0].save(join(IMAGE_SAVE_DIR, TRANSPARENT_BG, 'single_' + filename))
        cleaned_img[1].save(join(IMAGE_SAVE_DIR, TRANSPARENT_BG, 'double_' + filename))
        # cleaned_img.save(join(IMAGE_SAVE_DIR, TRANSPARENT_BG, filename))
        img.save(join(IMAGE_SAVE_DIR, WHITE_BG, filename))

import os
from os.path import join, exists
import time
from selenium import webdriver
from selenium.webdriver.common.by import By
from selenium.webdriver.support.ui import WebDriverWait
from selenium.webdriver.support import expected_conditions as EC
from selenium.common.exceptions import TimeoutException
from joblib import Parallel, delayed 
from time import sleep
from datetime import datetime
from bs4 import BeautifulSoup
import pandas as pd


import logging
logger = logging.getLogger("mylogger")
logger.setLevel(logging.INFO)
sh = logging.StreamHandler()
sh.setFormatter(logging.Formatter("%(asctime)s %(levelname)-8s %(message)s"))
fh = logging.FileHandler('log.txt', mode='a')
fh.setFormatter(logging.Formatter("%(asctime)s %(levelname)-8s %(message)s"))
logger.addHandler(sh)
logger.addHandler(fh)


RIVALS_DIR = 'rivals'
TEAMS_DIR = 'teams'
if not exists(join(RIVALS_DIR, TEAMS_DIR)):
    os.makedirs(join(RIVALS_DIR, TEAMS_DIR))


def get_team_rankings_by_year(year):
    PAGE_LOAD_TIMEOUT = 60
    options = webdriver.ChromeOptions()

    options.add_argument('--headless')
    # options.headless = True
    options.add_argument('--no-sandbox')
    options.add_argument('--disable-dev-shm-usage')
    # open it, go to a website, and get results
    driver = webdriver.Chrome('/Users/bleathers/Documents/Personal/wiki_table_scrape_uga_scores/chromedriver_mac64/chromedriver', options=options)
    driver.get(f'https://n.rivals.com/team_rankings/{year}/all-teams/football')
    
    time.sleep(5)
    tag_name = 'rv-team-rankings'
    WebDriverWait(driver, PAGE_LOAD_TIMEOUT).until(EC.presence_of_element_located((By.TAG_NAME, tag_name)))
    # element = WebDriverWait(driver, PAGE_LOAD_TIMEOUT).until(EC.presence_of_element_located((By.XPATH, "//span[@class='ordinality ng-binding ng-scope' and @ng-if='category.dataType == \"rank\"' and text()='11']")))
    html = driver.page_source 
    dfs = pd.read_html(html)
    driver.close()
    return [x for x in dfs if 'POINTS' in x.columns][0]

def format_plot(ax, title, subtitle, x_label, y_label, title_font='NCAA Georgia Bulldog Bold', subtitle_font='Arial', axis_font='Arial', grid_color='#dddddd'):
    # Set title font
    
    
    # Set plot title, subtitle, and axis labels
    ax.set_title(title, fontsize=18+2)
    # ax.subtitle(subtitle)
    ax.set_xlabel(x_label, fontsize=12)
    ax.set_ylabel(y_label, fontsize=12)
    
    ax.set_title(ax.get_title(), fontdict={'fontname': title_font, 'fontsize': 18})
    # ax.set_title(ax.get_title(), fontdict={'fontfamily': title_font, 'fontsize': 18})

    # Set subtitle font
    for item in ax.texts:
        if item.get_text() != ax.get_title():
            item.set_fontsize(14)
            item.set_fontname(subtitle_font)

    # Set axis font
    for item in ([ax.xaxis.label, ax.yaxis.label] +
                 ax.get_xticklabels() + ax.get_yticklabels()):
        item.set_fontname(axis_font)
        item.set_fontsize(12)

    # Add grid
    ax.grid(color=grid_color, linestyle='--')

    # Adjust padding
    plt.tight_layout()
    return ax

    path = "data/" + sub_dir
    isExist = os.path.exists(path)
    if not isExist:
        os.makedirs(path)
    with open(path + '/' + filename, 'w') as f:
        f.write(data)

def load_to_df(folder):
    if len(folder) < 4 or folder[:4] != 'data':
        folder = 'data/' + folder
        
    dir_list = os.listdir(folder)
    df = None
    for file in dir_list:
        if file[0] == '.':
            continue
        with open(folder + '/' + file, 'r') as f:
            year = json.loads(f.read())
        year_df = pd.json_normalize(year)
        year_df['year'] = int(file.split('_')[-1].split('.')[0])
        if df is None:
            df = year_df.copy()
        else:
            df = pd.concat([df, year_df])
    return df

def load_lines_to_df(folder, record_path, meta):
    if len(folder) < 4 or folder[:4] != 'data':
        folder = 'data/' + folder
        
    dir_list = os.listdir(folder)
    df = None
    for file in dir_list:
        if file[0] == '.':
            continue
        with open(folder + '/' + file, 'r') as f:
            year = json.loads(f.read())
        year_df = pd.json_normalize(year, record_path=record_path, meta=meta)
        # year_df['year'] = int(file.split('_')[-1].split('.')[0])
        if df is None:
            df = year_df.copy()
        else:
            df = pd.concat([df, year_df])
    return df

(12050, 23)



cur = conn.cursor()


query = """
WITH draft_picks AS (
    SELECT
        year - 1 AS year,
        college_athlete_id,
        college_id,
        college_team,
        overall,
        round,
        name
    FROM get_draft_picks
    WHERE college_team IS NOT NULL
    AND year IS NOT NULL
    )
, coaches AS (
    SELECT
        first_name || " " || last_name AS coach_name, 
        school AS college_team,
        year AS year        
    FROM get_coaches
)

, combined AS (
    SELECT
        year,
        coach_name,
        COUNT(overall) AS num_drafted
    FROM draft_picks
    LEFT JOIN coaches USING (college_team, year)
    WHERE coach_name IS NOT NULL
    GROUP BY 1, 2
)
, sorted AS (
SELECT
    year, 
    coach_name,
    college_team,
    SUM(num_drafted) OVER (PARTITION BY coach_name ORDER BY year ASC) AS cumulative_number_drafted,
    ROW_NUMBER() OVER (PARTITION BY coach_name ORDER BY year ASC) AS year_coached
FROM combined
JOIN coaches USING (coach_name, year)
)

SELECT
    *
FROM sorted
WHERE year_coached = 6
ORDER BY cumulative_number_drafted DESC
"""
cur.execute(query).fetchall()

section: ‚ÄúAll Time‚Äù includes the future, and while Saban might be the greatest in history, when it‚Äôs all said and done, Kirby will be the G.O.A.T.
text: ‚ÄúAll Time‚Äù includes the future, and while Saban might be the greatest in history, when it‚Äôs all said and done, Kirby will be the G.O.A.T.

Nick Saban won‚Äôt be the G.O.A.T.


An NFL Draft Perspective


By: Ben Leathers


2023-04-17


Clickbait headline aside, Nick Saban is unquestionably the greatest coach in history. However, the interesting thing about ‚Äúall time‚Äù is that it includes the future. Kirby Smart is only 7 seasons into his career as a head coach, and he‚Äôs been quite prolific when it comes to putting players into the draft. With the 2023 Draft coming up next week, I wanted to see how the start of Kirby‚Äôs head coaching career has looked so far and how he compares to other coaches at the beginning their careers, including Nick Saban. Finally, we‚Äôll look at how his trajectory projects into the future. But first, let‚Äôs start with Kirby.


How well has UGA put players into the draft while Kirby Smart has been the head coach?






Wow‚Ä¶ could that ‚Äúup and to the right‚Äù trajectory suggest that Kirby‚Äôs good at player development?


You might be thinking to yourself‚Ä¶ ‚ÄúNo, it just suggests he‚Äôs recruiting better players‚Äù which is a reasonable thing to think. Mark Richt is no question a DGD, and he elevated the program during his tenure. That being said, Kirby inherited a roster whose previous 3 recruiting classes had an average ranking of ~9th in the country, whereas Kirby has averaged rankings of ~3rd as head coach of UGA. So you would be justified to argue that this upward trajectory just points to better recruiting. But is there more to the story?






It‚Äôs not just better players. Even the 3 stars are more likely to get drafted the longer they play under Kirby.


How do UGA‚Äôs Draft results during Kirby‚Äôs first 6 years compare to other coach‚Äôs first 6 years?






Seeing Jimbo Fisher at #5 was surprising to begin with, but then I remembered he‚Äôs got a reputation for recruiting and he‚Äôs developing a reputation for losing recruits now that the transfer portal is a factor. Mark Richt at #6 is less surprising, he was a great coach who did put a lot of talent into the NFL.


So how did Larry Coker and Jim Tressel out perform Kirby in the first 6 years?






Oh, they stepped into programs with loaded rosters that put 8 and 11 players into the NFL in year 1. Kirby didn‚Äôt inherit a completely bare roster, but it was certainly more modest.


How many UGA players will need to be drafted in order for Kirby to jump into first in year 7?






What Happened to Larry Coker?


He got fired from Miami after going 6-6 and didn‚Äôt coach again until 2012 when he was hired by UTSA.


Let‚Äôs check on some coaches that are noticibly absent from the top ten.






In fairness to Saban he didn‚Äôt start his heach coaching careers at a blue blood football school, so lets compare the results from the start of each school‚Äôs tenure.









Kirby‚Äôs start at UGA is out pacing any of Saban‚Äôs starts. However, we don‚Äôt call him the greatest in history for no reason, so let‚Äôs see how things compare when we look at ANY 6 year span‚Ä¶



And there it is. Saban has spent the last 11 years churning out NFL talent at an unprecedented level, and thus he currently occupies the top 6 spots in that ranking.


So while Kirby has certainly gotten the flywheel of player development up to speed quicker than anyone else, the question is, can he sustain that? According to his post G-Day press conference last weekend, UGA is ‚Äúbuilt to sustain‚Ä¶ That‚Äôs my motto.‚Äù, and by all accounts that looks to be the case.


Let‚Äôs take a look at Saban‚Äôs entire career to get an idea of what it looks like to sustain, and where the bar has been set.






Wow. That puts ‚Äúsustain‚Äù into perspective. Saban has over 25 years as a head coach, and he‚Äôs sustained greatness over that span. Kirby has gotten off to an elite start. Only time will tell if he‚Äôll be able to sustain long enough to cement himself as the G.O.A.T.



Takeaways:


Kirby‚Äôs program develops players.


Kirby‚Äôs Death Star might not have even been fully operational yet‚Ä¶ ü§Ø


‚ÄúAll Time‚Äù includes the future, and while Saban might be the greatest in history, Kirby is on the path to take over and when it‚Äôs all said and done‚Ä¶


Saban will not be the G.O.A.T., Kirby will.


This analysis was based on an open source dataset, cfbd, and while I‚Äôm confident in my work, I am also confident I‚Äôm human, so if you find a mistake, please let me know.

title: nfl_draft_review
text:
Nick Saban won‚Äôt be the G.O.A.T.


Part 1: The NFL Draft


By: Ben Leathers


2023-04-17


Clickbait headline aside, Nick Saban is unquestionably the greatest coach in history. However, the interesting thing about ‚Äúall time‚Äù is that it includes the future. While many think Saban will be the G.O.A.T., Kirby Smart, who‚Äôs coming off of back to back national championships, is seven years down a war path aimed at claiming the G.O.A.T. title.


There are many apects of a coach‚Äôs career that will be referenced when fans engage in the G.O.A.T. debate, and I look forward to exploring them all, but with the 2023 NFL Draft happening next week and Kirby Smart coming off a record setting year with fifteen players drafted in 2022, I wanted to wet the series whistle with a focus on the NFL Draft production for their respective careers. Let‚Äôs begin with Kirby, whose head coaching career began in 2016.


How well has UGA put players into the draft while Kirby Smart has been the head coach?






Wow‚Ä¶ could that ‚Äúup and to the right‚Äù trajectory suggest that Kirby‚Äôs good at player development?


You might be thinking to yourself‚Ä¶ ‚ÄúNo, it just suggests he‚Äôs recruiting better players‚Äù which is a reasonable thing to think. Mark Richt is no question a DGD (‚ÄúDamn Good Dawg‚Äù, for any non-Georgia fans), and he elevated the program during his tenure. That being said, Kirby inherited a roster whose previous three recruiting classes had an average ranking of ~9th in the country, whereas Kirby has averaged rankings of ~3rd as head coach of UGA. So you would be justified to argue that this upward trajectory just points to better recruiting. But is there more to the story?






It‚Äôs not just better players. Even recruits rated 3-stars or lower are more likely to get drafted the longer they play under Kirby.
